htmlEmbed:
Third round of free coronavirus tests made available by U.S. governmentKatie Shepherd4/17/2022

Households can now order eight additional tests, boosting supplies ahead of possible summer and fall surges.

HealthRead

data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Households can now order eight more free at-home coronavirus tests, the White House <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/05/17/fact-sheet-the-biden-administration-announces-americans-can-order-additional-free-at-home-rapid-covid-19-tests-at-covidtests-gov/" target="_blank">said Tuesday</a>, giving Americans access to an additional supply of rapid tests ahead of possible summer and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/05/06/fall-winter-coronavirus-wave/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target="_blank">fall surges.</a></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“As the highly transmissible subvariants of Omicron drive a rise in cases in parts of the country, free and accessible tests will help slow the spread of the virus,” the White House said in a statement. The tests are available at <a href="https://www.covid.gov/tests" target=_blank>covid.gov/tests.</a></p></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The Biden administration previously committed to making 1 billion at-home tests available to American households at no charge and has so far distributed 350 million tests. Households were allowed to order four tests at a time in January and March.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Cases <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/05/17/latest-coronavirus-wave-us/?itid=lk_inline_manual_8">have been rising</a> in some parts of the United States, though it is difficult to gauge how widely the highly transmissible omicron subvariants have spread. Home testing has become more common at the same moment that local health officials have dropped many mitigation efforts and scaled back data collection. Positive home tests are only included in the official case count when the test-taker reports their result or confirms it with a PCR test.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/05/17/latest-coronavirus-wave-us/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_9">How big is the latest U.S. coronavirus wave? No one really knows.</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The Biden administration earlier this month warned that a summertime spike in cases across the South could exhaust the nation’s supply of tests and antivirals, and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/05/06/fall-winter-coronavirus-wave/?itid=lk_inline_manual_10">predicted that a possible fall surge</a> could infect as many as 100 million Americans.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">As of Tuesday, much of the Northeast — including most of New York, and parts of Delaware, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine — had reached high community levels of transmission, <a href="https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#county-view?list_select_state=all_states&list_select_county=all_counties&data-type=CommunityLevels&null=CommunityLevels">according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a>. Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Montana, Washington and Hawaii also each have at least one county with a high level of transmission.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Despite the rise in cases and a modest increase in hospitalizations in several regions, the numbers remain far below the levels seen during the peak of the January omicron wave.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">During past surges, at-home tests have been <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/01/13/covid-tests-google-biden/?itid=lk_inline_manual_15">difficult to find on store shelves</a>. But the test kits last for several months, and experts say that having tests on hand can help mitigate transmission during a sudden spike in cases.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/national/coronavirus-us-cases-deaths/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_16">Tracking the coronavirus</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The White House on Tuesday again urged Congress to fund President Biden’s covid preparedness efforts, including allocating more money to maintain the nation’s testing capacity and provide treatments to people who test positive for the virus. Republicans have been <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2022/05/11/congress-covid-aid-ukraine/?itid=lk_inline_manual_17" target=_blank>blocking a covid funding deal</a> because of an unrelated dispute over immigration policy.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“Due to Congress’s failure to provide additional funding for the nation’s COVID-19 response, the Administration cannot continue making the types of federal investments needed to sustain domestic testing manufacturing capacity,” the White House said in a statement Tuesday. “This may jeopardize the federal government’s ability to provide free tests moving forward.”</p></div><div class="mb-lg-mod hide-for-print" id="link-box"><div data-qa="content" class="linkbox-content"><h3 class="font-md font-bold font--headline offblack lh-md pb-xs" data-qa="linkbox-headline">Coronavirus: What you need to read</h3><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>The latest: </b>BA.5 is the most recent omicron offshoot, and it’s quickly become the dominant strain in the U.S. <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/07/10/omicron-variant-ba5-covid-reinfection/" target=_blank>Here’s what to know about it</a>, and why vaccines may only offer limited protection.</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Vaccines:</b> Will you need a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/04/20/when-to-get-second-covid-booster/" target=_blank>fourth coronavirus vaccine</a>? Expect a booster shot <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/06/30/omicron-vaccine-booster-fall/" target=_blank>specifically targeting the omicron variant</a> to roll out this fall, and immunizations for <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/06/21/coronavirus-vaccine-under-5/" target=_blank>children under 5</a> became available this summer. You can also <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/health/covid-vaccine-states-distribution-doses/?itid=sn_coronavirus_4/" target=_blank>track how many Americans have been vaccinated</a>.</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Mask guidance:</b> You aren’t required to wear a mask when flying anymore, but most experts <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/travel/2022/04/19/mask-plane-covid-health-experts/" target=_blank>still say you should</a>. We created <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/04/20/when-to-still-mask-planes/" target=_blank>a guide to help you decide when to keep wearing face coverings</a>.</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Where do things stand?</b> See the latest coronavirus numbers <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/national/coronavirus-us-cases-deaths/?state=US" target="_blank">in the U.S.</a> and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/mapping-spread-new-coronavirus/" target="_blank">across the world</a>. The <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/interactive/2021/tracker-omicron-spread/" target="_blank">omicron variant</a> is behind much of the recent spread.</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"></p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"></p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><i>For the latest news, </i><a href="https://subscribe.washingtonpost.com/newsletters/#/bundle/health?method=SURL&location=ART"><i>sign up for our free newsletter</i></a><i>.</i></p></div><div class="flex justify-center relative"></div></div><div class="flex mt-md"><div class="mb-lg-mod" data-qa="comments-btn-div"><button class="inline-flex readabilityObject.title: Third round of free coronavirus tests made available by U.S. government
readabilityObject.content:
Households can now order eight more free at-home coronavirus tests, the White House said Tuesday, giving Americans access to an additional supply of rapid tests ahead of possible summer and fall surges.

“As the highly transmissible subvariants of Omicron drive a rise in cases in parts of the country, free and accessible tests will help slow the spread of the virus,” the White House said in a statement. The tests are available at covid.gov/tests.

The Biden administration previously committed to making 1 billion at-home tests available to American households at no charge and has so far distributed 350 million tests. Households were allowed to order four tests at a time in January and March.

Cases have been rising in some parts of the United States, though it is difficult to gauge how widely the highly transmissible omicron subvariants have spread. Home testing has become more common at the same moment that local health officials have dropped many mitigation efforts and scaled back data collection. Positive home tests are only included in the official case count when the test-taker reports their result or confirms it with a PCR test.

The Biden administration earlier this month warned that a summertime spike in cases across the South could exhaust the nation’s supply of tests and antivirals, and predicted that a possible fall surge could infect as many as 100 million Americans.

As of Tuesday, much of the Northeast — including most of New York, and parts of Delaware, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine — had reached high community levels of transmission, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Montana, Washington and Hawaii also each have at least one county with a high level of transmission.

Despite the rise in cases and a modest increase in hospitalizations in several regions, the numbers remain far below the levels seen during the peak of the January omicron wave.

During past surges, at-home tests have been difficult to find on store shelves. But the test kits last for several months, and experts say that having tests on hand can help mitigate transmission during a sudden spike in cases.

The White House on Tuesday again urged Congress to fund President Biden’s covid preparedness efforts, including allocating more money to maintain the nation’s testing capacity and provide treatments to people who test positive for the virus. Republicans have been blocking a covid funding deal because of an unrelated dispute over immigration policy.

“Due to Congress’s failure to provide additional funding for the nation’s COVID-19 response, the Administration cannot continue making the types of federal investments needed to sustain domestic testing manufacturing capacity,” the White House said in a statement Tuesday. “This may jeopardize the federal government’s ability to provide free tests moving forward.”
